current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To amend the Commodity Exchange Act to improve futures and swaps trading, and for other purposes.

header.#text: Reporting of illiquid swaps so as to not disadvantage certain non-financial end users

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 15(a) of the Commodity Exchange Act

header.#text:
Analysis by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of the costs and benefits of regulations and
			 orders

text.#text: Before promulgating a regulation under this Act or issuing an order (except as provided in
state a justification for the regulation or order;

assess the costs and benefits, both qualitative and quantitative, of the intended regulation or
			 order;
measure, and seek to improve, the actual results of regulatory requirements; and

propose or adopt a regulation or order only on a reasoned determination that the benefits of the
			 intended
			 regulation or order justify the costs of the intended regulation or order
			 (recognizing that
			 some benefits and costs are difficult to quantify).
In making a reasoned determination of costs and benefits under
the protection of market participants and the public;
the efficiency, competitiveness, and financial integrity of futures and swaps markets;
the impact on market liquidity in the futures and swaps markets;
the cost of available alternatives to direct regulation;

the degree and nature of the risks posed by various activities within the scope of the jurisdiction
			 of the

whether, consistent with obtaining regulatory objectives, the regulation or order is tailored to
			 impose the
			 least burden on society, including market participants, individuals,
			 businesses of differing sizes, and other entities (including small
			 communities and governmental entities), taking into account, to the extent
			 practicable, the cumulative costs of regulations and orders;

whether the regulation or order is inconsistent, incompatible, or duplicative of other Federal
			 regulations and orders; and

whether, in choosing among alternative regulatory approaches, those approaches maximize net
			 benefits (including potential economic, environmental, and other benefits,
			 distributive impacts, and equity).
